title: RL32937
content: The Senate Finance Committee and the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Human Resources have approved legislation to reauthorize and revise the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) Block Grant, including changes to the Child Support Enforcement (CSE) program. S. 667 and H.R. 240 were reported by the Senate Finance Committee and approved by the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Human Resources in March 2005. The Child Support Enforcement (CSE) program, enacted in 1975, is part of the government's social safety net. It is administered by the Office of Child Support Enforcement (OCSE) in the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and funded by general revenues. All 50 states, the District of Columbia, Guam, Puerto Rico, and the Virgin Islands operate CSE programs. The Child Support Enforcement (CSE) program, established in 1975 under Title IV of the Social Security Act, is administered by the Office of Child Support Enforcement (OCSE) in the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS). The report compares the assignment rules for TANF benefits and child support payments, detailing how families must assign their child support rights to the state to receive TANF benefits. Assigned child support collections are kept by states and the federal government as reimbursement for welfare benefits. Nonwelfare families applying for CSE services do not assign their child support rights. The date of assignment determines the treatment of arrearages. The assignment date determines how child support arrearages are treated: if assigned before September 30, 1997, all arrearages are permanently assigned to the state; if assigned after October 1, 1997, only arrearages accumulated during assistance are permanently assigned. Pre-assistance arrearages are temporarily assigned and revert back to the family when they leave TANF. Under S. 667 as reported by the Senate Finance Committee, child support arrearages accrued before the family started receiving TANF benefits would not be covered by the assignment. Only arrearages that accumulate while the family receives TANF benefits are permanently assigned to the state. The child support assignment under S. 667 as reported by the Senate Finance Committee would only cover child support that accrues while the family receives TANF benefits. This means that any child support arrearages that accrued before the family started receiving TANF benefits would not have to be assigned to the state, and any child support collected for pre-assistance arrearages would go to the family. In contrast, H.R. 240 as approved by the House Ways and Means Subcommittee on Human Resources does not make any changes regarding the child support assignment.
